> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On 

> > Consider the following business logic:
> > 
> > 1) Start server
> > 2) Create connection pool
> > 3) Send message
> > 4) Receiver of message stores values in the DB
> > 
> > In order to test these four steps, it makes sense to accumulate the 
> > state of the previous phases so that you don't have to recreate it 
> > from scratch.
> 
> I'd actually prefer to decouple the four steps in a way that 
> recreating the state one of those steps needs isn't too hard.
> 
> Each of those steps already sounds complex enough to test on 
> its own. We will probably want to have more than one test for 
> each, which will likely lead to a "combinatorical explosion" 
> if we test all the four steps together.

The combinatorial explosion appears if you don't maintain state.  With this
approach, your tests are going to look like:

Test1:
	1
Test2:
	1-2
Test3:
	1-2-3
Test4:
	1-2-3-4

This is a huge waste of time.  Testing application servers and more
importantly, applications that run in these application servers, can take
several hours to entire nights (trust me on that :-)), so the approach above
is simply not applicable.

And it also raises the problem I mentioned earlier (if test 2 fails, tests 3
and 4 should not be marked as FAILURES but as TESTS NOT RUN, which is much
less scary to the QA organization).
